elements.content: A series of novel lanthanide metal–organic frameworks were synthesized using a ligand featuring three carboxylate groups stationed on a triazinyl central motif. The readily accessible multiple Lewis basic triazinyl N atoms allow for complexation of incoming metal ions. Such interactions have been established quantitatively.
elements.clean_text: A series of novel lanthanide metal-organic frameworks were synthesized using a ligand featuring three carboxylate groups stationed on a triazinyl central motif. The readily accessible multiple Lewis basic triazinyl N atoms allow for complexation of incoming metal ions. Such interactions have been established quantitatively.

elements.content: Adding metal ions to the lanthanide metal−organic frameworks containing multiple Lewis basic triazinyl N sites led to significant enhancement or quenching of luminescence because of the different nature of the metal guest−ligand interactions and suggesting potential sensory applications.
elements.clean_text: Adding metal ions to the lanthanide metal-organic frameworks containing multiple Lewis basic triazinyl N sites led to significant enhancement or quenching of luminescence because of the different nature of the metal guest-ligand interactions and suggesting potential sensory applications.

elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF) solids are a family of porous materials constructed by the assembly of metal-containing units with appropriate organic linking groups. The ability to tune the pore size and to incorporate various functions into the framework structure offers great promise for the development of materials that are useful for such diverse applications as recognition, separation, and storage of guest molecules of interest, sensing, drug delivery, and catalysis.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic framework (MOF) solids are a family of porous materials constructed by the assembly of metal-containing units with appropriate organic linking groups. The ability to tune the pore size and to incorporate various functions into the framework structure offers great promise for the development of materials that are useful for such diverse applications as recognition, separation, and storage of guest molecules of interest, sensing, drug delivery, and catalysis.

elements.content: Among the large number of MOFs, those displaying interesting luminescence properties, inherent or triggered by interactions with guest species, are receiving increasing current attention because they are useful for the development of sensing technologies among other applications. Of particular note are lanthanide-containing luminescent MOFs because of the propitious luminescence properties originating from the unique f electronic configurations of these elements. These include extremely sharp emissions and therefore high optical purity, high quantum yields when sensitized by effective ligand-to-metal energy transfer (also known as the “antenna effect”), and structural and compositional optimization of the ligands without affecting the emission characteristics of a chosen lanthanide. More significantly, because of the unique mechanism by which the emissive state of the lanthanide ion is populated, changes of lanthanide luminescence can be effected by a number of means. In this contribution, we report the synthesis, structure determination, and luminescence properties of an Eu3+-containing red-emitting MOF. It has been found that the red luminescence of the framework can be significantly enhanced or essentially completely quenched depending on the metal ions that the MOF was in contact with. The study of the relationship between such luminescence changes and the guest–MOF interactions is of significance for the development of metal-sensing systems.
elements.clean_text: Among the large number of MOFs, those displaying interesting luminescence properties, inherent or triggered by interactions with guest species, are receiving increasing current attention because they are useful for the development of sensing technologies among other applications. Of particular note are lanthanide-containing luminescent MOFs because of the propitious luminescence properties originating from the unique f electronic configurations of these elements. These include extremely sharp emissions and therefore high optical purity, high quantum yields when sensitized by effective ligand-to-metal energy transfer (also known as the "antenna effect"), and structural and compositional optimization of the ligands without affecting the emission characteristics of a chosen lanthanide. More significantly, because of the unique mechanism by which the emissive state of the lanthanide ion is populated, changes of lanthanide luminescence can be effected by a number of means. In this contribution, we report the synthesis, structure determination, and luminescence properties of an Eu3+-containing red-emitting MOF. It has been found that the red luminescence of the framework can be significantly enhanced or essentially completely quenched depending on the metal ions that the MOF was in contact with. The study of the relationship between such luminescence changes and the guest-MOF interactions is of significance for the development of metal-sensing systems.

elements.content: Our MOF, formulated as [Eu(BTPCA)(H2O)]·2DMF·3H2O [1; H3BTPCA = 1,1′,1″-(benzene-1,3,5-triyl)tripiperidine-4-carboxylic acid; DMF = dimethylformamide], was synthesized by keeping a mixture of LnCl3 and H3BTPCA in DMF/H2O at 65 °C. Isostructural MOFs containing trivalent Ce, Pr, and Nd (2–4) were also obtained under otherwise identical reaction conditions (Table S1 in the , SI). Thermal treatment of 1 removed the aqua ligand and the solvent molecules of crystallization, affording 1a, putatively the activated form of the porous solid. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of 1a is nearly identical with that of 1, indicating that the structural integrity of the framework is maintained (Figure S4 in the ). As expected, resolvation of 1a in water and DMF afforded respectively 1a·nH2O and 1a·nDMF, both producing the same XRD patterns as 1 and 1a. None of these different forms is soluble in water or common organic solvents.
elements.clean_text: Our MOF, formulated as [Eu(BTPCA)(H2O)]⋅2DMF⋅3H2O [1; H3BTPCA = 1,1',1"-(benzene-1,3,5-triyl)tripiperidine-4-carboxylic acid; DMF = dimethylformamide], was synthesized by keeping a mixture of LnCl3 and H3BTPCA in DMF/H2O at 65 °C. Isostructural MOFs containing trivalent Ce, Pr, and Nd (2-4) were also obtained under otherwise identical reaction conditions (Table S1 in the , SI). Thermal treatment of 1 removed the aqua ligand and the solvent molecules of crystallization, affording 1a, putatively the activated form of the porous solid. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of 1a is nearly identical with that of 1, indicating that the structural integrity of the framework is maintained (Figure S4 in the ). As expected, resolvation of 1a in water and DMF afforded respectively 1a⋅nH2O and 1a⋅nDMF, both producing the same XRD patterns as 1 and 1a. None of these different forms is soluble in water or common organic solvents.

elements.content: The structure of 1, shown in Figure , was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The electrically neutral framework is constructed by Eu3+ ions bridged by BTPCA ligands. Each BTPCA ligand coordinates six Eu3+ ions using exclusively its carboxylate groups, two of which are bridging/chelating and the third is bridging with each of its two O atoms coordinating one Ln3+ ion in a monodentate fashion (Figure a). The coordinatively identical Eu3+ ions are each nonacoordinate and are situated in a coordination sphere composed of nine O atoms from one aqua ligand and six different BTPCA ligands. The bridging interactions are responsible for organization of the metal atoms into a chain structure (Figure b) with microporous channels along the crystallographic c axis (Figures c and S5 and S6 in the ).
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1, shown in Figure , was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The electrically neutral framework is constructed by Eu3+ ions bridged by BTPCA ligands. Each BTPCA ligand coordinates six Eu3+ ions using exclusively its carboxylate groups, two of which are bridging/chelating and the third is bridging with each of its two O atoms coordinating one Ln3+ ion in a monodentate fashion (Figure a). The coordinatively identical Eu3+ ions are each nonacoordinate and are situated in a coordination sphere composed of nine O atoms from one aqua ligand and six different BTPCA ligands. The bridging interactions are responsible for organization of the metal atoms into a chain structure (Figure b) with microporous channels along the crystallographic c axis (Figures c and S5 and S6 in the ).

elements.content: (a) Linking of the BTPCA ligand to six different Ln3+ centers in the title complexes. (b) Chain with nonacoordination for the Ln3+ coordination environment in the title complexes. (c) Packing of 1 as viewed slightly off the c axis. The coordinated water molecules, free solvate molecules, and H atoms were omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Linking of the BTPCA ligand to six different Ln3+ centers in the title complexes. (b) Chain with nonacoordination for the Ln3+ coordination environment in the title complexes. (c) Packing of 1 as viewed slightly off the c axis. The coordinated water molecules, free solvate molecules, and H atoms were omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The luminescence spectra of H3BTPCA, the as-synthesized 1, the thermally activated form 1a, and the rehydrated form 1a·nH2O were recorded (Figures S7–S9 in the ). Upon excitation at 395 nm, 1 luminesces at 590, 618, 650, and 702 nm, characteristic of the Eu3+ ion and assignable to its 5D0 → 7F n (n = 1–4) transitions. The ligand-based emission at 445 nm was not observed, indicating that BTPCA is an excellent chromophore for sensitization of the Eu3+ ion. Thermal treatment of 1 removed the luminescence-quenching aqua ligand and hence the noticeable enhancement in the luminescence of 1a. Not unexpectedly, rehydration of 1a to 1a·nH2O caused significant luminescence quenching. These observations are consistent with the well-established fact that lanthanide luminescence can be effectively quenched through nonradiative decay due to vibronic coupling to high-energy vibrational states of the O–H and N–H bonds.
elements.clean_text: The luminescence spectra of H3BTPCA, the as-synthesized 1, the thermally activated form 1a, and the rehydrated form 1a⋅nH2O were recorded (Figures S7-S9 in the ). Upon excitation at 395 nm, 1 luminesces at 590, 618, 650, and 702 nm, characteristic of the Eu3+ ion and assignable to its 5D0 → 7F n  (n = 1-4) transitions. The ligand-based emission at 445 nm was not observed, indicating that BTPCA is an excellent chromophore for sensitization of the Eu3+ ion. Thermal treatment of 1 removed the luminescence-quenching aqua ligand and hence the noticeable enhancement in the luminescence of 1a. Not unexpectedly, rehydration of 1a to 1a⋅nH2O caused significant luminescence quenching. These observations are consistent with the well-established fact that lanthanide luminescence can be effectively quenched through nonradiative decay due to vibronic coupling to high-energy vibrational states of the O-H and N-H bonds.

elements.content: The Lewis basic triazinyl N atoms of the ligand, directed into the channels of the framework and thus exposed, are supposedly available for interactions with Lewis acidic analytes. Such interactions are expected to alter the electronic structure of the BTPCA ligand that dictates the ligand-to-Eu3+ energy transfer and determines the overall effectiveness of sensitization of the emissive lanthanide ion. Indeed, the samples M z+-1b obtained by immersing 1a in DMF solutions containing various metal ions displayed markedly different luminescence. As shown in Figure , when in contact with Fe3+, the red luminescence of 1a·nDMF, monitored at 618 nm for the 5D0 → 7F2 transition, was essentially completely quenched. In stark contrast, the interaction with Zn2+ drastically enhanced the luminescence intensity, with a maximum of more than 3.5 times as much as that of the parent MOF. The rest of the metal ions (K+, Al3+, Cr3+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Cu2+) tested did not cause any significant change to the intensity of the luminescence (Figures S10–S16 in the ). Of particular relevance to the present work is [Eu(PDC)1.5(DMF)]·0.5DMF·0.5H2O (PDC = pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate), a luminescent MOF reported by Chen and co-workers. The addition of Cu2+ led to reduction of the Eu3+-originated luminescence to about 50% of its original intensity. The authors speculated that binding of Cu2+ by the pyridyl N atom of the PDC ligand is responsible because of a compromised antenna effect.
elements.clean_text: The Lewis basic triazinyl N atoms of the ligand, directed into the channels of the framework and thus exposed, are supposedly available for interactions with Lewis acidic analytes. Such interactions are expected to alter the electronic structure of the BTPCA ligand that dictates the ligand-to-Eu3+ energy transfer and determines the overall effectiveness of sensitization of the emissive lanthanide ion. Indeed, the samples M z+-1b obtained by immersing 1a in DMF solutions containing various metal ions displayed markedly different luminescence. As shown in Figure , when in contact with Fe3+, the red luminescence of 1a⋅nDMF, monitored at 618 nm for the 5D0 → 7F2 transition, was essentially completely quenched. In stark contrast, the interaction with Zn2+ drastically enhanced the luminescence intensity, with a maximum of more than 3.5 times as much as that of the parent MOF. The rest of the metal ions (K+, Al3+, Cr3+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Cu2+) tested did not cause any significant change to the intensity of the luminescence (Figures S10-S16 in the ). Of particular relevance to the present work is [Eu(PDC)1.5(DMF)]⋅0.5DMF⋅0.5H2O (PDC = pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate), a luminescent MOF reported by Chen and co-workers. The addition of Cu2+ led to reduction of the Eu3+-originated luminescence to about 50% of its original intensity. The authors speculated that binding of Cu2+ by the pyridyl N atom of the PDC ligand is responsible because of a compromised antenna effect.

elements.content: Comparison of the luminescence intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition of M z+-1b versus 1a·nDMF (λex = 344 nm). The inset shows the photographs of M z+-1b under light and UV-light irradiation.
elements.clean_text: 2  Comparison of the luminescence intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition of M z+-1b versus 1a⋅nDMF (λex = 344 nm). The inset shows the photographs of M z+-1b under light and UV-light irradiation.

elements.content: With the hopes of unambiguously establishing the interactions between the metal-ion guests and the MOF host, a series of titration-like experiments were carried out in which the luminescence intensity of the sample obtained by immersing a fixed amount of 1a in a DMF solution of a specific concentration of Fe3+ or Zn2+ was measured. As illustrated by Figure a, the luminescence intensity decreases as the concentration of Fe3+ increases. Quantitatively, the luminescence was essentially completely quenched when a 3:1 Fe3+/1a molar ratio is reached (Figure b), clearly suggesting complexation of the luminescence-quenching Fe3+ with the three triazinyl N atoms of the BTPCA ligand; an increase in the amount of Fe3+ beyond the equivalence point does not lead to any further changes. The same metal-to-1a stoichiometry of 3:1 was obtained by measuring the enhancement of luminescence upon the addition of Zn2+ (Figures S17 and S18 in the ), providing further support to the aforementioned of M z+–N(triazinyl) coordination.
elements.clean_text: With the hopes of unambiguously establishing the interactions between the metal-ion guests and the MOF host, a series of titration-like experiments were carried out in which the luminescence intensity of the sample obtained by immersing a fixed amount of 1a in a DMF solution of a specific concentration of Fe3+ or Zn2+ was measured. As illustrated by Figure a, the luminescence intensity decreases as the concentration of Fe3+ increases. Quantitatively, the luminescence was essentially completely quenched when a 3:1 Fe3+/1a molar ratio is reached (Figure b), clearly suggesting complexation of the luminescence-quenching Fe3+ with the three triazinyl N atoms of the BTPCA ligand; an increase in the amount of Fe3+ beyond the equivalence point does not lead to any further changes. The same metal-to-1a stoichiometry of 3:1 was obtained by measuring the enhancement of luminescence upon the addition of Zn2+ (Figures S17 and S18 in the ), providing further support to the aforementioned of M z+-N(triazinyl) coordination.

elements.content: (a) Excitation (λem = 618 nm) and emission (λex = 344 nm) spectra of the solid samples of Fe3+-1b obtained by immersing 1a in DMF solutions with different concentrations of FeCl3. (b) Luminescence intensity of Fe3+-1b monitored at 618 nm versus the concentration of Fe3+.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Excitation (λem = 618 nm) and emission (λex = 344 nm) spectra of the solid samples of Fe3+-1b obtained by immersing 1a in DMF solutions with different concentrations of FeCl3. (b) Luminescence intensity of Fe3+-1b monitored at 618 nm versus the concentration of Fe3+.

elements.content: The putative sensitization of the Eu3+ ion for luminescence via energy transfer mediated by the BTPCA ligand is illustrated in Figure . The process starts with excitation of the ligand, followed by energy transfer to the emissive states of the Eu3+ ion. Complexation following the introduction of metal-ion guests into the MOF channels is expected to perturb the electronic structure of the ligand; both the singlet and triplet excited states may be affected. These changes, in turn, will affect how effectively the emissive states of the Eu3+ ion are sensitized and hence the observed changes in the luminescence intensity.
elements.clean_text: The putative sensitization of the Eu3+ ion for luminescence via energy transfer mediated by the BTPCA ligand is illustrated in Figure . The process starts with excitation of the ligand, followed by energy transfer to the emissive states of the Eu3+ ion. Complexation following the introduction of metal-ion guests into the MOF channels is expected to perturb the electronic structure of the ligand; both the singlet and triplet excited states may be affected. These changes, in turn, will affect how effectively the emissive states of the Eu3+ ion are sensitized and hence the observed changes in the luminescence intensity.

elements.content: Pictorial description of energy-transfer processes, leading to ligand-sensitized Eu3+ luminescence in the Eu3+ organic framework 1a. Legend: green polyhedra, [EuO8]; gray spheres, C atoms; blue spheres, N atoms.
elements.clean_text: 4  Pictorial description of energy-transfer processes, leading to ligand-sensitized Eu3+ luminescence in the Eu3+ organic framework 1a. Legend: green polyhedra, [EuO8]; gray spheres, C atoms; blue spheres, N atoms.

elements.content: The diffuse-reflectance UV–visible spectra of 1a·nDMF and Mz+-1b (Figures S19 and S20 in the ) suggest that the strong absorption of Fe3+-1b at the excitation wavelength (344 nm) is possibly responsible for the observed quenching of luminescence, which effectively suppresses transfer of the excitation energy to Eu3+ and therefore population of the emissive states, corroborating the shortest luminescence lifetime of Fe3+-1b (Figure S25 in the ). Because the lanthanide-originated luminescence is typically in the micro- to millisecond range, the nanosecond lifetime of the luminescence of Fe3+-1b clearly indicates that the emissive state of the Eu3+ ion is essentially unpopulated. In other words, the energy-transfer pathway from the ligand to the emissive center is blocked. In contrast, consistent with the observed significant enhancement of luminescence, Zn2+-1b displays the weakest absorption at the same wavelength (Table S2 in the ) and the longest luminescence lifetime (Figure S26 in the ). As a representative for the other metal ions that do not show significant influence on the luminescence intensity, the decay profile of Cu2+-1b is shown in Figure S24 in the . Not surprisingly, it is very similar to those of 1, 1a, and 1a·nDMF (Figures S21–S23 in the ). Additionally, the quantum yields for 1a·nDMF and Zn-1b are 16% and 49%, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The diffuse-reflectance UV-visible spectra of 1a⋅nDMF and Mz+-1b (Figures S19 and S20 in the ) suggest that the strong absorption of Fe3+-1b at the excitation wavelength (344 nm) is possibly responsible for the observed quenching of luminescence, which effectively suppresses transfer of the excitation energy to Eu3+ and therefore population of the emissive states, corroborating the shortest luminescence lifetime of Fe3+-1b (Figure S25 in the ). Because the lanthanide-originated luminescence is typically in the micro- to millisecond range, the nanosecond lifetime of the luminescence of Fe3+-1b clearly indicates that the emissive state of the Eu3+ ion is essentially unpopulated. In other words, the energy-transfer pathway from the ligand to the emissive center is blocked. In contrast, consistent with the observed significant enhancement of luminescence, Zn2+-1b displays the weakest absorption at the same wavelength (Table S2 in the ) and the longest luminescence lifetime (Figure S26 in the ). As a representative for the other metal ions that do not show significant influence on the luminescence intensity, the decay profile of Cu2+-1b is shown in Figure S24 in the . Not surprisingly, it is very similar to those of 1, 1a, and 1a⋅nDMF (Figures S21-S23 in the ). Additionally, the quantum yields for 1a⋅nDMF and Zn-1b are 16% and 49%, respectively.

elements.content: In summary, a luminescent MOF composed of a Eu3+ ion and a tricarboxylate ligand was synthesized and structurally characterized. Effective sensitization of the metal ion by the ligand is demonstrated. The readily accessible Lewis basic N atoms of the ligand allow for metal–ligand complexation with incoming metal-ion guests. Depending on the nature of the interaction and the resulting perturbation to the electronic structure of the ligand, the efficiency of ligand-to-lanthanide energy transfer is affected, leading to compromised or enhanced population of the lanthanide emissive states and, ultimately, the quenching or enhancement of Eu3+ luminescence. The essentially complete quenching and drastic enhancement of Eu3+ luminescence upon the respective incorporation of Fe3+ and Zn2+ ions suggest specifically the potential use of the MOF for metal-ion sensing.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a luminescent MOF composed of a Eu3+ ion and a tricarboxylate ligand was synthesized and structurally characterized. Effective sensitization of the metal ion by the ligand is demonstrated. The readily accessible Lewis basic N atoms of the ligand allow for metal-ligand complexation with incoming metal-ion guests. Depending on the nature of the interaction and the resulting perturbation to the electronic structure of the ligand, the efficiency of ligand-to-lanthanide energy transfer is affected, leading to compromised or enhanced population of the lanthanide emissive states and, ultimately, the quenching or enhancement of Eu3+ luminescence. The essentially complete quenching and drastic enhancement of Eu3+ luminescence upon the respective incorporation of Fe3+ and Zn2+ ions suggest specifically the potential use of the MOF for metal-ion sensing.

elements.content:
X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format, synthesis, characterization, and properties of 1–4. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

metadata.title:
Cation
Sensing by a Luminescent Metal–Organic Framework with Multiple
Lewis Basic Sites
